Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: అழுக்காறு உடையார்க்கு அதுசாலும் ஒன்னார்வழுக்காயும் கேடீன் பது.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: To those who cherish envy that is enough. Though free from enemies that (envy) will bring destruction.

Layered_Composition.Foreground: An envious person ('అழுக்காறு உடையார்') stands alone in a barren landscape.
Layered_Composition.Midground: They have no external enemies; the land around them is empty of foes ('ஒன்னார் வழுக்காயும்').
Layered_Composition.Background: However, their own envy is personified as a monstrous, shadowy serpent that lives within their own heart. This inner serpent is shown emerging and striking its own host, delivering a fatal, destructive poison ('கேடு ஈன்பது'). Their own envy is all the enemy they need to cause their ruin.

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: For an envious person, their own envy is a sufficient enemy to guarantee their destruction, even if they have no other foes.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: Envy as a self-destroying serpent within the heart is the central, powerful metaphor. The absence of external enemies highlights the fact that the destruction is entirely self-inflicted.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: A bleak, lonely light. The envious person is cast in a sickly green-yellow glow. The serpent of envy is a creature of dark, venomous shadow. The scene is one of internal decay and self-destruction.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A surreal, symbolic shot that shows a cross-section of the person's chest, revealing the serpent of envy striking from within.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, ultra-realistic, with a terrifying and monstrous design for the personified envy.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: The only significant light comes from the sickly glow of the envy itself.

Cultural_Anchors: For the envious, that alone is enough (అழுக்காறு உடையார்க்கு அது சாலும்)
